componenttextpreview: Sure, Lorraine. We don't disclose the specific percentage for competitive reasons. That said, as with most retailers, a good portion of our apparel and footwear comes from China. So with that said, in terms of the mitigation, so as we mentioned in the com
componenttext: Sure, Lorraine. We don't disclose the specific percentage for competitive reasons. That said, as with most retailers, a good portion of our apparel and footwear comes from China. So with that said, in terms of the mitigation, so as we mentioned in the commentary, we think it was a prudent approach to make our best estimate of a potential impact, separating out what goes into effect in September and December. And for us, our best estimate at this point is we added $0.03 -- or took $0.03 from EPS in the back half. But certainly, I hope it plays out more favorably, but that's our best shot at this point in time. I mean, we'll have to wait to see. As Barbara mentioned, how different retailers react to the higher cost, their approach on pricing as well as how the consumer would react to increase in prices. That said, historically, disruptions like this had been beneficial for off-price.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Mark Altschwager from Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Mark Altschwager from Baird.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you could give a bit more color on some of the gross margin drivers in Q2 just in terms of merch margin, freight distribution. And then if you're able to quantify perhaps just the level of merch margin pressure you expect from tariffs over th
componenttext: I was hoping you could give a bit more color on some of the gross margin drivers in Q2 just in terms of merch margin, freight distribution. And then if you're able to quantify perhaps just the level of merch margin pressure you expect from tariffs over the back half, that'd be helpful.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: On merch margin piece, we wouldn't disclose the margin impact, but the $0.03 that we included in the guidance is largely merchandise margin.
componenttext: On merch margin piece, we wouldn't disclose the margin impact, but the $0.03 that we included in the guidance is largely merchandise margin.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: And then let me just provide a little bit more detail. So during the period, cost of goods sold increased 10 basis points. Higher merchandise margin and lower distribution cost of 10 basis points each were offset by freight cost that rose 20 basis points,
componenttext: And then let me just provide a little bit more detail. So during the period, cost of goods sold increased 10 basis points. Higher merchandise margin and lower distribution cost of 10 basis points each were offset by freight cost that rose 20 basis points, and occupancy deleverage of 10 basis points. Buying expenses were flat versus last year. Selling and general administrative expenses for the quarter increased 5 basis points, largely due to higher wage cost.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Kimberly Greenberger from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Kimberly Greenberger from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: I wanted to explore SG&A a little bit more. Wage is obviously still growing here in the second quarter. If you could give us any sort of order of magnitude on the wage growth headwind to SG&A here in Q2 that will be helpful. And will that change as we loo
componenttext: I wanted to explore SG&A a little bit more. Wage is obviously still growing here in the second quarter. If you could give us any sort of order of magnitude on the wage growth headwind to SG&A here in Q2 that will be helpful. And will that change as we look out to the back half of the year? And on the cost -- the SG&A cost shift out of Q2, do you have -- I think you said that was $0.02 benefit to the second quarter. If you could give us the SG&A dollars benefiting Q2, and if that's expected to come in Q3 or Q4? Just any color on that would be helpful.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Kimberly, as you may recall, we increased wages across the board last year to $11. So we are just now anniversarying that in the second quarter. When we entered the year, despite wage growth, our own $11 increase and the minimum wage increases in states l
componenttext:
Kimberly, as you may recall, we increased wages across the board last year to $11. So we are just now anniversarying that in the second quarter. When we entered the year, despite wage growth, our own $11 increase and the minimum wage increases in states like California, we guided the year for SG&A to leverage at the normal 3%. So we've been able to offset those costs. 
In terms of the $0.02 timing, that wasn't all in SG&A. Some of that's gross margin, and we wouldn't break out that specific. And as a reminder, the $0.02 timing benefit was versus our original guidance not versus last year.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Omar Saad from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Omar Saad from Evercore ISI.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Could you talk about some of the women's apparel trends? I know it's improved a little bit but still kind of lingering issues there. Is that more external fashion trends? Or external factors related to the category and environment or internal execution is
componenttext: Could you talk about some of the women's apparel trends? I know it's improved a little bit but still kind of lingering issues there. Is that more external fashion trends? Or external factors related to the category and environment or internal execution issues that you think you can address? And I also would love to get your thoughts on some of the lower freight rates we're hearing about this year and into next year if that's material to you guys.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: I'll start with the freight. So generally for us, freight has played out much as we expected at the beginning of the year. What we saw was 35 basis point deleverage in Q1, 20 basis points deleverage in Q2. And our guidance assumes that it will abate furth
componenttext: I'll start with the freight. So generally for us, freight has played out much as we expected at the beginning of the year. What we saw was 35 basis point deleverage in Q1, 20 basis points deleverage in Q2. And our guidance assumes that it will abate further in the back half.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: And as it pertains to the women's apparel trends, externally, there isn't any one major big trend driving Ladies apparel. I mean I think that's the first thing. But with that, our issues in Ladies apparel really related to our own execution issues, brough
componenttext: And as it pertains to the women's apparel trends, externally, there isn't any one major big trend driving Ladies apparel. I mean I think that's the first thing. But with that, our issues in Ladies apparel really related to our own execution issues, brought our assortments below our normal standard. So we feel like we've been working through those issues, we feel like we've made some progress, still trailing the chain. And as I said before, in my comments, we feel like as the year goes on, that the business will continue to improve.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Michael Binetti from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Michael Binetti from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Congrats on a nice quarter. Just a, Michael, question on your comments on the near term. I think you mentioned that you closed an inventory for back-to-school or earlier to -- maybe some color on whether you think that strategy seems successful in the ear
componenttext:
Congrats on a nice quarter. Just a, Michael, question on your comments on the near term. I think you mentioned that you closed an inventory for back-to-school or earlier to -- maybe some color on whether you think that strategy seems successful in the early days?
And then you did make a comment on observing department store trend lately, and you're hunched that we could see promotions stepping up. Maybe just a little more color about how you're looking at the landscape? And what you're planning your business for given the competitive set that you expect in the back half? And I have a follow up.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sure, Michael. We wouldn't comment on kind of inter-quarter trends at this point. We would do that in -- at the end of Q3. And my comments really on the department store is just based on their earnings performance. So they obviously -- the comps were cert
componenttext: Sure, Michael. We wouldn't comment on kind of inter-quarter trends at this point. We would do that in -- at the end of Q3. And my comments really on the department store is just based on their earnings performance. So they obviously -- the comps were certainly below the off-price and value performers, plus on top of that, their gross margins, which would suggest they were more promotional, and that could continue into Q3.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I hate to ask the most basic question, but maybe a little color on inventories you're seeing available. Are you seeing things that excite you? And more importantly, maybe why? Is it better brands? New categories opening up? I'm a little surprise
componenttext: Okay. And I hate to ask the most basic question, but maybe a little color on inventories you're seeing available. Are you seeing things that excite you? And more importantly, maybe why? Is it better brands? New categories opening up? I'm a little surprised packaway was lower year-over-year given what we're seeing in the market, and the Ross to get product in before the tariffs this year. So I'm wondering if we're going to -- if your plan includes -- are we going to see that total inventory number built into 3Q. Any thoughts on that?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: So in terms of supply, supply is very plentiful. It is broad across most classifications of business. In terms of the level of packaway, packaway fluctuates and the merchants fight at the way they see it in terms of the products, the timing, the pricing o
componenttext: So in terms of supply, supply is very plentiful. It is broad across most classifications of business. In terms of the level of packaway, packaway fluctuates and the merchants fight at the way they see it in terms of the products, the timing, the pricing of those goods. And so it's still in the 40s range, which is pretty average for us. But the merchants have to make that decision. So as the season goes on, they'll continue to see additional goods. As department store business -- if it continues to be difficult, you would expect that there would be more supply in the shorter term, and we're liquid and ready to take advantage of those opportunities once the merchants feel that it's at the right price and the right value as we're anticipating it being a very promotional fourth quarter. So...

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Alex Walvis from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Alex Walvis from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: The first question that I had is whether you can help us out with the breakdown of the comp between traffic, where you are in basket. Second question was a follow up on the inventory, in-store inventory growth. Can you talk about the drivers of the decisi
componenttext: The first question that I had is whether you can help us out with the breakdown of the comp between traffic, where you are in basket. Second question was a follow up on the inventory, in-store inventory growth. Can you talk about the drivers of the decision to flow receipts earlier, is that all of the reason for the slightly higher in-store inventory? Or is there anything else going on there?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Travis. In terms of the components of sales, the 3% comp was driven by slightly higher traffic, and an increase in the size of the average basket. A higher basket was driven by higher units per transaction. Its AUR was down just a bit for the
componenttext: Yes, this is Travis. In terms of the components of sales, the 3% comp was driven by slightly higher traffic, and an increase in the size of the average basket. A higher basket was driven by higher units per transaction. Its AUR was down just a bit for the quarter.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: And on inventory, it was a function on flowing receipts earlier. It was in our plan at the beginning of the year. And so that was strategic.
componenttext: And on inventory, it was a function on flowing receipts earlier. It was in our plan at the beginning of the year. And so that was strategic.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Great. And one follow up, if I may. The men's business has been strong for some time. Can you talk about what's working there? And where the continued strength is coming from?
componenttext: Great. And one follow up, if I may. The men's business has been strong for some time. Can you talk about what's working there? And where the continued strength is coming from?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sure. I would tell you. So the reason the men's business is good because we have a solid strategy that the merchants have done a very good job of executing on. So our level of execution there has been very consistent, and again, as has the strategy. So th
componenttext: Sure. I would tell you. So the reason the men's business is good because we have a solid strategy that the merchants have done a very good job of executing on. So our level of execution there has been very consistent, and again, as has the strategy. So there's not one particular thing that's really driving it.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Daniel Hofkin from William Blair.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Daniel Hofkin from William Blair.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick questions. And I apologize I missed a little bit, so if you've already answered that, no worries. But as it relates to the -- you talked a little bit about, it was SG&A and gross margin both had a little bit of timing of expenses. B
componenttext: Just a couple of quick questions. And I apologize I missed a little bit, so if you've already answered that, no worries. But as it relates to the -- you talked a little bit about, it was SG&A and gross margin both had a little bit of timing of expenses. But just curious, did inventory flow timing affect the gross margin? And if so, was that -- how much roughly was that? And then just if you haven't already given it, some additional color by region and category beyond just sort of the main ones, if you have that.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Dan, on the inventory flow, it just happened at the end of the quarter. So no, it did not have an impact on margins. Margin for the quarter was up 10 basis points, that was a little lower than the benefit that we saw in Q3. That was somewhat impacted by t
componenttext: Dan, on the inventory flow, it just happened at the end of the quarter. So no, it did not have an impact on margins. Margin for the quarter was up 10 basis points, that was a little lower than the benefit that we saw in Q3. That was somewhat impacted by the tariffs that went into effect in June, but we were able to offset that with strong expense control. And then...

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: And then by -- in terms of color or geographic region, as we mentioned in our commentary, the Midwest and Southeast were the strongest regions. Of our other major markets, California and Florida were slightly below the chain while Texas and the Southwest
componenttext: And then by -- in terms of color or geographic region, as we mentioned in our commentary, the Midwest and Southeast were the strongest regions. Of our other major markets, California and Florida were slightly below the chain while Texas and the Southwest were a bit better than the chain average. In terms of merchandise categories, we mentioned men's was the strongest category. Children's was also pretty strong.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from John Morris from D.A. Davidson.
componenttext: Your next question comes from John Morris from D.A. Davidson.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Congratulations on a nice quarter as well. Barbara, maybe can you give us a little bit more color on dd's, and the progress that you're making there, and what you're particularly pleased with? And sort of how you're benchmarking it?And then 2 other kind
componenttext:
Congratulations on a nice quarter as well. Barbara, maybe can you give us a little bit more color on dd's, and the progress that you're making there, and what you're particularly pleased with? And sort of how you're benchmarking it?
And then 2 other kind of quick housekeeping questions. One is, we talked a little bit about inventory in the plan but can you give us a sense of where inventory at the end of Q3 might be related to sales? I mean same kind of growth about in line, I'm assuming.
And I don't know if you would answer this or not, I'm just kind of curious, we've talked a lot about freight, but it's just a kind of quick one. Does freight contracts -- when you're negotiating terms, is that an annual event with somebody or is it kind of a continuous thing? It kind of helps us understand how it should flow through.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sure. You started going through those, we don't give forward-looking guidance on inventory levels. And on freight, for us, we have already gone through our annual renewals, we did that earlier this year. So we have some pretty good visibility at this poin
componenttext: Sure. You started going through those, we don't give forward-looking guidance on inventory levels. And on freight, for us, we have already gone through our annual renewals, we did that earlier this year. So we have some pretty good visibility at this point.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: And as it pertains to dd’s, as we said before, we've had strong growth both in sales and profit. But for competitive reasons, we don't really get more specific than that other than to say that dd’s has a similar four-wall profit margin to Ross.
componenttext: And as it pertains to dd’s, as we said before, we've had strong growth both in sales and profit. But for competitive reasons, we don't really get more specific than that other than to say that dd’s has a similar four-wall profit margin to Ross.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Paul Trussell from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Paul Trussell from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: I'm curious to hear what you are seeing in terms of new store performance both on the Ross and dd’s side.
componenttext: I'm curious to hear what you are seeing in terms of new store performance both on the Ross and dd’s side.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Travis. Our new store performance is pretty consistent with our historical averages of between 60% and 65% of an average comp. It fluctuates a little bit quarter-to-quarter, depending on where the new stores are located, but overall, the perf
componenttext: Yes, this is Travis. Our new store performance is pretty consistent with our historical averages of between 60% and 65% of an average comp. It fluctuates a little bit quarter-to-quarter, depending on where the new stores are located, but overall, the performance is pretty consistent.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: And just sort of -- just a bigger picture, just curious if there is any thoughts around e-commerce as you look in the years ahead?
componenttext: And just sort of -- just a bigger picture, just curious if there is any thoughts around e-commerce as you look in the years ahead?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: On e-commerce, our view on e-commerce has not changed. We think in the moderate off-price business, the economics are just not sustainable. Over many years now, we've posted comp sales that are at the high end of retail benchmarks, and we've done this wit
componenttext: On e-commerce, our view on e-commerce has not changed. We think in the moderate off-price business, the economics are just not sustainable. Over many years now, we've posted comp sales that are at the high end of retail benchmarks, and we've done this without e-commerce. So rather than being distracted by what we view as unsustainable business, we'd rather focused ourselves on what's proven and -- proven to be very profitable opportunity in front of us.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Congratulations on recent promotions.
componenttext: Congratulations on recent promotions.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Paul.
componenttext: Thank you, Paul.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Ike Boruchow from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Ike Boruchow from Wells Fargo.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Just on the cap -- on the CapEx spend. I think you guys guided it to $600 million this year. I'm just curious, is that still the right number? And then I think there is a new DC build out embedded in there. I'm just trying to understand what maybe the run
componenttext: Just on the cap -- on the CapEx spend. I think you guys guided it to $600 million this year. I'm just curious, is that still the right number? And then I think there is a new DC build out embedded in there. I'm just trying to understand what maybe the run rate of CapEx should be into next year. And then to whoever wants to answer it. Should there be some kind of supply chain pressure on margin at some point? I'm not sure if you're already seeing that or maybe something we should keep in mind our models next year? Just any color on that.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: So the DC. I'll let Travis cover the capital, but the DC next couple of years. So we would expect to open, so we would not expect any impact of that new DC as we move into 2020.
componenttext: So the DC. I'll let Travis cover the capital, but the DC next couple of years. So we would expect to open, so we would not expect any impact of that new DC as we move into 2020.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: In terms of total capital spend, it hasn't changed. We're still expecting to spend around $600 million this year, about 1/3 of that is related to distribution center buildouts and -- et cetera. In terms of going forward, again, I think we've said in the p
componenttext: In terms of total capital spend, it hasn't changed. We're still expecting to spend around $600 million this year, about 1/3 of that is related to distribution center buildouts and -- et cetera. In terms of going forward, again, I think we've said in the past, we expect total capital spending to be elevated for a couple of years.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jay Sole from UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jay Sole from UBS.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: I have a question about the $0.03 impact on tariffs. Is that a net number, meaning is there sort of like a $0.06 headwind that's being offset with $0.03 of cost cutting or other mitigation factors? Or is it just $0.03, this would be actual impact of the t
componenttext: I have a question about the $0.03 impact on tariffs. Is that a net number, meaning is there sort of like a $0.06 headwind that's being offset with $0.03 of cost cutting or other mitigation factors? Or is it just $0.03, this would be actual impact of the tariff is?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. On that question. So obviously, we had the tariffs -- we started the year with 10% tariffs on Tranche 3, which was mainly in categories like home, cosmetics and accessories. That expanded to 25% in June. We were able to mitigate those tariff impacts
componenttext: Yes. On that question. So obviously, we had the tariffs -- we started the year with 10% tariffs on Tranche 3, which was mainly in categories like home, cosmetics and accessories. That expanded to 25% in June. We were able to mitigate those tariff impacts with tightening our belts on cost. With this, this $0.03 is our best estimate on what the margin could impact -- margin impact could be. And at this point, don't think we can offset that with cost reduction. And again, hope it plays out more favorably than this.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Right. And then Barbara, I wanted to ask you is, if apparel is a category, it's a little bit slower and there's some opportunities to do more business in categories like [ Petsi Pies ] or auto parts or food, or some of the newer categories in the store. H
componenttext: Right. And then Barbara, I wanted to ask you is, if apparel is a category, it's a little bit slower and there's some opportunities to do more business in categories like [ Petsi Pies ] or auto parts or food, or some of the newer categories in the store. How do those -- what's the interplay like between those categories and some of your more traditional categories like apparel and footwear? How does the customer experience change if they're coming in to buy apparel, if they're also kind of looking at auto parts and [ Petsi Pies ] and toys and food and other things that maybe they're not used to seeing in the store?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Well, I actually think the customer likes it because it enhances the treasure hunt, right? So I come in, thinking I'm going to buy something in Ladies, say, and I go to Ladies, and I looked at Ladies. And this customer likes to touch and feel. Likes to se
componenttext: Well, I actually think the customer likes it because it enhances the treasure hunt, right? So I come in, thinking I'm going to buy something in Ladies, say, and I go to Ladies, and I looked at Ladies. And this customer likes to touch and feel. Likes to see new things and something that they didn't do the last time they were in the store. Average customer shops at store more than 3 times a month. So we think it's exciting, and the customer enjoys having something new. The challenge is to keep continually adding new things to make the treasure hunt -- make her come back again and again with exciting and new products.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from John Kernan from Cowen.
componenttext: Your next question comes from John Kernan from Cowen.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about any emerging competitive threat from the growth of resale? There has been some industry chatter about it recently, there has been some executives within that channel talking about the share that they're stealing from off-price. Have you
componenttext: Can you talk about any emerging competitive threat from the growth of resale? There has been some industry chatter about it recently, there has been some executives within that channel talking about the share that they're stealing from off-price. Have you seen any effects of that? Do you think that this is any type of a long-term competitive threat? And then I have one quick follow up.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: I would say, over the long term, we've competed with -- against many different types of retail concepts, brands, department stores, specialty stores and have done extremely well. So we don't see it as a long-term competitive threat.
componenttext: I would say, over the long term, we've competed with -- against many different types of retail concepts, brands, department stores, specialty stores and have done extremely well. So we don't see it as a long-term competitive threat.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Got it. Then maybe can you just talk about the performance of Home. It feels like as if the category in general has become a little bit more competitive recently. Can you talk about your specific performance?
componenttext: Got it. Then maybe can you just talk about the performance of Home. It feels like as if the category in general has become a little bit more competitive recently. Can you talk about your specific performance?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sure. Home, for the quarter, performed in line with the chain. We still continue to see it as a long-term growth opportunity because it's obviously a wide assortment of products. But performance in line with the chain, we're never fully satisfied with any
componenttext: Sure. Home, for the quarter, performed in line with the chain. We still continue to see it as a long-term growth opportunity because it's obviously a wide assortment of products. But performance in line with the chain, we're never fully satisfied with any part of our business. So we would like to continue to expand and to growth that business. But for competitive reasons, I wouldn't talk more about the specifics of that. I mean, what actually...

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Janine Stichter from Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Janine Stichter from Jefferies.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019

componenttext: Just had a quick follow up on the tariffs just for modeling purposes. Is there any major variation we should think about in terms of how the tariffs flow through? Which comes through in September versus what flows through in December?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: We -- because we haven't given fourth quarter guidance at this point, it's hard to say other than we have embedded the $0.03 into the back half guidance. I think if you've looked at the -- it doesn't start post September. And I think if you look at the in
componenttext: We -- because we haven't given fourth quarter guidance at this point, it's hard to say other than we have embedded the $0.03 into the back half guidance. I think if you've looked at the -- it doesn't start post September. And I think if you look at the industry, I would say that there's more of the apparel and shoes in the September tranche than in the December tranche. So that's the color I'd add to that.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Laura Champine from Loop Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Laura Champine from Loop Capital.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019

componenttext: It's about the mechanics of getting to the $0.03 impact from tariffs. Since you've got such an open -- significant open to buy, I'm wondering whether you just calculated that by looking at what you bought year ago period from China?

componenttext: Well, remember our business. So there is a small portion of our business where we directly import [indiscernible]. Our thought is that over the majority of the goods that we procure in apparel and shoes is -- was originally sourced from China. That said, it's hard to know what's going to happen at this point. I mean it just was announced several weeks ago in the markets. What I would say is, the majority of our business is closeout. So if you look at what we have left to buy year-over-year, we would normally have a lot of closeout in our receipt plan for the remainder of the year.

As you think about the expense timing shift that went on, how much to go each quarter as you think about in the third and fourth quarter? And is there anything in particular that shifted from the second quarter to the back half? 
And just lastly, how you're thinking of marketing for the back half of the year? Any changes in what you're spending? Or what you're doing?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: In terms of the timing, I just want to reiterate that the timing difference is versus our original guidance. So that $0.02 flows into our back half guidance. And so we wouldn't break that out between Q3 and Q4. On marketing, our marketing strategy and m
componenttext:
In terms of the timing, I just want to reiterate that the timing difference is versus our original guidance. So that $0.02 flows into our back half guidance. And so we wouldn't break that out between Q3 and Q4. 
On marketing, our marketing strategy and message has been very consistent over the years and hasn't changed for us. The message is we offer the best values in apparel and home fashions. We think, frankly that marketing can help support our business, but what really drives our business is great bargains in the store. If we have great assortments then marketing can help support that trend.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019

componenttext: I wanted to ask 2 things, one about AUR, wondering if it was down slightly on mix or pricing. And then secondly, I'm wondering just in the context of the plentiful inventory availability. So far this year and going forward, if you are looking to change your mix or have the opportunity to change your mix, if you so desire, between good, better and best product?

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. In terms of AUR, the decline was primarily driven by the change in mix of sell-through within categories.
componenttext: Yes. In terms of AUR, the decline was primarily driven by the change in mix of sell-through within categories.

headline: Ross Stores, Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Aug 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: And in terms of the availability and the changing of our mix. We're going to take advantage of whatever we think the best deals are out there. We don't go in there and say, I want the x amount of all purchases to be good, to be better and to be best. We g
componenttext: And in terms of the availability and the changing of our mix. We're going to take advantage of whatever we think the best deals are out there. We don't go in there and say, I want the x amount of all purchases to be good, to be better and to be best. We go, obviously, with the best possible deals and values are for the customer, and that's how we purchase it. So the merchants are out buying it the way we see it. It's not as much top-down as you might think, it's really more of bottom-up, based on the deals, based on the values that they can deliver.

componenttext: Yes, Paul. So we always like to start the year with guidance. And then as we move through the year, make sure we update you on how that impacts. So that's all we're calling out in the guidance.
